ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Textbook
live virtual lecture, one-on-one TA sessions and recorded lectures
tutorial session
Met four times per week on Zoom, had weekly office hours

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read basic Chinese and some Chinese grammar.
This class was really great - learned Chinese characters, pinyin, grammar, and speech.
I was able to easily read, write, speak, and understand chinese, learning over 300 characters.
basic chinese memorization
Before this course, my knowledge of Mandarin was very very basic. After one semester, I was able to learn 500 new characters!
I primarily focused on writing and reading simplified Chinese, as well as building up my vocabulary. I also improved with conversational Chinese.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: a small group of peers, fast-paced character learning that applied to readings, weekly tutoring sessions. Weaknesses: None
This class was a great introduction to chinese language; it can be further improved by relating that to modern chinese culture.

Strengths include interactive practice with the language everyday and being patient with our learning, Weaknesses include a heavy workload and many soft deadlines for major assignments so I never knew when things were due.
The workload is lot; however, I thought the course was extremely rewarding. I was able to learn 500+ characters in just one semester!

I love how rigorous this course is, and how we meet every single day and have assignments and quizzes due each day. Every single one of us improved greatly! However, I wish we had more room for creative projects.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Among all my classes this was the most well-adapted to COVID-19! Since this is a language class I was involved in every class since we had to utilize what we were learning in conversation. The breakout rooms were also fun and we got to practice our speaking, as well as reading/writing, regularly.
I think that was an example of a course that was translated really well to the virtual learning environment. It would be nice to implement additional one-on-one time with the instructor.
I liked how we were put into breakout rooms; this allowed me to meet new people and to practice my Chinese.
I like how we often used breakout rooms to practice conversations with classmates. I don't think much could've been improved with virtual learning in this course!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Especially if you are a heritage student, learning Chinese is extremely meaningful. And you will definitely make a lot of friends.
If a student is interested in learning or using the chinese language then absolutely!

Yes I would recommend this course. The professor is so nice and treats all of their students with kindness, always excited for classes and equally allowing us to participate during class. The professor is very understanding about a student's personal concerns whether it's feeling like their struggling with something or in need of an extension, etc.
yes
I would recommend this course to any student who has very basic knowledge of Mandarin. I only knew a couple of phrases before taking this course, but I was still able to keep up and learn a lot.
Definitely consider taking the heritage track if you can understand Chinese well.
I definitely would recommend this to any heritage speaker of Chinese at Yale! The course is such a pleasure, and really kickstarts your Chinese learning.
